==Japanese==

===Kanji===
{{ja-kanji|grade=|rs=木09}}

# [[maple]]
# ''[[Liquidambar formosana]]'', {{vern|Chinese sweetgum tree}}, {{vern|Formosan sweetgum tree}}

====Readings====
{{ja-readings
|goon=[[ふう]] (fū)
|kanon=[[ほう]] (hō)
|kun=[[かえで]] (kaede), [[かいで]] (kaide), [[かつら]] (katsura), [[おかつら]] (okatsura)
}}

====Compounds====
{{der-top|Compounds}}
'''Kun'yomi''':
* {{ja-r|楓科|かえでか}}: the maple family, ''[[Aceraceae]]''
* {{ja-r|楓棚|かえでだな}}: a type of shelf in a ''[[tokonoma]]'' or study, with four legs and eight shelves
* {{ja-r|楓鳥|かえでちょう}}, {{ja-r|カエデチョウ|かえでちょう}}: the {{vern|black-rumped waxbill}}, a type of {{vern|estrildid finch}} common in Africa and introduced to Japan in the 1960s
* {{ja-r|楓鳥科|かえでちょうか}}, {{l|ja|カエデチョウ科|かえでちょうか}}: [[genus]] ''[[Estrilda]]''
* {{ja-r|楓紅葉|かえで もみじ}}: maple leaves that have turned red in autumn; a style of layered clothing with light yellow-green on the outside and yellow or orange-red on the inside
'''On'yomi''':
* {{ja-r|楓蚕|ふうさん}}: alternate for {{m|ja|天蚕蛾|tr=tegusuga||Japanese silkworm moth, {{taxlink|Antheraea yamamai|species|noshow=1}}}}
* {{ja-r|風樹|ふうじゅ}}: the {{vern|Formosan gum tree}}; the maple
* {{ja-r|楓糖|ふうとう}}: [[maple syrup]]
* {{ja-r|楓葉|ふうよう}}: maple leaves that have turned red in autumn
{{der-bottom}}

===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|カエデ}}
{{wikipedia|Maple}}
[[File:Acer_palmatum_002.JPG|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|楓}} (''kaede''): '''[[maple]]''' leaves and seeds.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|かえで}}
Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=かえで|蛙|tr1=kaeru|t1=frog|手|tr2=te|t2=hand}}, with the ''te'' changing to ''de'' due to {{rendaku|かえで}}, and the ''ru'' dropping out over time. From the way the [[palmate]] leaves resemble a frog's foot.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|かえで|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|槭}}, {{l|ja|槭樹}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かえで|hhira=かへで}}

# the [[maple]] tree
# a [[color scheme]] for {{m|ja|襲|tr=kasane|lit=layering||layered kimono}}, where both the outer and inner layers are [[light green]]
# a kind of {{m|ja|家紋|tr=kamon||family crest}}, featuring a maple-leaf design
# {{lb|ja|sort=かえで|term of endearment}} a [[child]]'s hand {{qualifier|from the resemblance in shape between a hand with [[splayed]] fingers and a maple leaf}}

=====Usage notes=====
{{U:ja:biology|カエデ}}

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|楓の木|かえで の き}}, {{ja-r|楓の樹|かえで の き}}: a maple [[tree]]
* {{ja-r|楓の間|^かえで の ^ま}}: the Maple Room, one of the [[shogun]] [[sitting room]]s in {{w|Edo Castle}}
{{der-bottom}}

====Proper noun====
{{ja-pos|proper|かえで}}

# {{given name|female|lang=ja|sort=かえで}}.

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|かいで}}
Shift in pronunciation of ''kaede''.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|かいで}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かいで}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=かいで|uncommon}} alternate reading for ''kaede'': the [[maple]] tree

===Etymology 3===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|カツラ (植物)}}
{{wikipedia|Cercidiphyllum japonicum}}
[[File:Cercidiphyllum_japonicum2.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|楓}} (''katsura''): '''[[katsura]]''' leaves and seeds.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|かつら}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=かつら}}. Less common spelling for {{m|ja|桂|tr=''katsura''}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|かつら|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かつら}}

# {{ja-def|桂}} the [[katsura]] tree, ''[[Cercidiphyllum japonicum]]''
# {{ja-def|桂}} {{lb|ja|sort=かつら|Chinese mythology}} the kind of tree that grows on the [[moon]]

=====Usage notes=====
{{U:ja:biology|カツラ}}

The ''katsura'' reading is rare for this kanji. When referring to the ''katsura'' tree, the {{ja-l|桂}} spelling is used more often to avoid confusion.

===Etymology 4===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|おかつら}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=おかつら}}. Alternate spelling for {{m|ja|男桂|tr=okatsura||male katsura}}, an archaic name for the katsura tree.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> Compare {{m|ja|女桂|tr=mekatsura||female katsura: the cinnamon tree}}. Appears with this reading in the {{m|ja|和名類聚抄|tr={{w|Wamyō Ruijushō}}}}, a Japanese dictionary of Chinese characters completed in 938.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|おかつら}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|おかつら|hhira=をかつら}} {{ja-altread|hira=おかづら|rom=okazura}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=おかつら|obsolete}} the [[katsura]] tree, ''[[Cercidiphyllum japonicum]]''

===Etymology 5===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|フウ}}
{{wikipedia|Liquidambar formosana}}
[[File:Liquidambar_formosana_02.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|楓}} (''fū''): '''[[sweetgum]]''' leaves and seeds.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|ふう}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=ふう}} {{m|zh|楓|tr=biung}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|ふう|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|ふう}}

# {{ja-def|フウ}} the [[Formosan]] [[sweetgum]] [[tree]], ''[[Liquidambar formosana]]''
# in certain kanji compounds, the [[maple]] tree

=====Usage notes=====
{{U:ja:biology|フウ}}

=====Idioms=====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|楓呉江に落つ|ふう ^ごこう に おつ}}: “the ''fū'' leaves falling in Wujiang” → being disappointed in the reality of something after having lofty ideas about it; from a story in the ''{{w|New Book of Tang}}'' about an inspiring poem from an otherwise uninspiring poet
* {{ja-r|楓葉衰えて盧橘花開く|ふうよう おとろえて ろきつ はな ひらく}}: “the red sweetgum/maple leaves fade, and the kumquat flowers open” → a metaphor for the turning of the seasons
{{der-bottom}}
